summary.long: Romans is a book of the New Testament.

verses.text: This letter is from Paul, a slave of Christ Jesus, chosen by God to be an apostle and sent out to preach his Good News.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God promised this Good News long ago through his prophets in the holy Scriptures.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Good News is about his Son. In his earthly life he was born into King David’s family line,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he was shown to be the Son of God when he was raised from the dead by the power of the Holy Spirit. He is Jesus Christ our Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Through Christ, God has given us the privilege and authority as apostles to tell Gentiles everywhere what God has done for them, so that they will believe and obey him, bringing glory to his name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And you are included among those Gentiles who have been called to belong to Jesus Christ.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am writing to all of you in Rome who are loved by God and are called to be his own holy people.
May God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ give you grace and peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let me say first that I thank my God through Jesus Christ for all of you, because your faith in him is being talked about all over the world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God knows how often I pray for you. Day and night I bring you and your needs in prayer to God, whom I serve with all my heart by spreading the Good News about his Son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of the things I always pray for is the opportunity, God willing, to come at last to see you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I long to visit you so I can bring you some spiritual gift that will help you grow strong in the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we get together, I want to encourage you in your faith, but I also want to be encouraged by yours.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I want you to know, dear brothers and sisters, that I planned many times to visit you, but I was prevented until now. I want to work among you and see spiritual fruit, just as I have seen among other Gentiles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I have a great sense of obligation to people in both the civilized world and the rest of the world, to the educated and uneducated alike.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I am eager to come to you in Rome, too, to preach the Good News.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I am not ashamed of this Good News about Christ. It is the power of God at work, saving everyone who believes—the Jew first and also the Gentile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This Good News tells us how God makes us right in his sight. This is accomplished from start to finish by faith. As the Scriptures say, “It is through faith that a righteous person has life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God shows his anger from heaven against all sinful, wicked people who suppress the truth by their wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They know the truth about God because he has made it obvious to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For ever since the world was created, people have seen the earth and sky. Through everything God made, they can clearly see his invisible qualities—his eternal power and divine nature. So they have no excuse for not knowing God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, they knew God, but they wouldn’t worship him as God or even give him thanks. And they began to think up foolish ideas of what God was like. As a result, their minds became dark and confused.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Claiming to be wise, they instead became utter fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And instead of worshiping the glorious, ever-living God, they worshiped idols made to look like mere people and birds and animals and reptiles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So God abandoned them to do whatever shameful things their hearts desired. As a result, they did vile and degrading things with each other’s bodies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They traded the truth about God for a lie. So they worshiped and served the things God created instead of the Creator himself, who is worthy of eternal praise! Amen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is why God abandoned them to their shameful desires. Even the women turned against the natural way to have sex and instead indulged in sex with each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the men, instead of having normal sexual relations with women, burned with lust for each other. Men did shameful things with other men, and as a result of this sin, they suffered within themselves the penalty they deserved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since they thought it foolish to acknowledge God, he abandoned them to their foolish thinking and let them do things that should never be done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their lives became full of every kind of wickedness, sin, greed, hate, envy, murder, quarreling, deception, malicious behavior, and gossip.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They are backstabbers, haters of God, insolent, proud, and boastful. They invent new ways of sinning, and they disobey their parents.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They refuse to understand, break their promises, are heartless, and have no mercy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They know God’s justice requires that those who do these things deserve to die, yet they do them anyway. Worse yet, they encourage others to do them, too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You may think you can condemn such people, but you are just as bad, and you have no excuse! When you say they are wicked and should be punished, you are condemning yourself, for you who judge others do these very same things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And we know that God, in his justice, will punish anyone who does such things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since you judge others for doing these things, why do you think you can avoid God’s judgment when you do the same things?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t you see how wonderfully kind, tolerant, and patient God is with you? Does this mean nothing to you? Can’t you see that his kindness is intended to turn you from your sin?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But because you are stubborn and refuse to turn from your sin, you are storing up terrible punishment for yourself. For a day of anger is coming, when God’s righteous judgment will be revealed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will judge everyone according to what they have done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will give eternal life to those who keep on doing good, seeking after the glory and honor and immortality that God offers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he will pour out his anger and wrath on those who live for themselves, who refuse to obey the truth and instead live lives of wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There will be trouble and calamity for everyone who keeps on doing what is evil—for the Jew first and also for the Gentile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But there will be glory and honor and peace from God for all who do good—for the Jew first and also for the Gentile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For God does not show favoritism.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Gentiles sin, they will be destroyed, even though they never had God’s written law. And the Jews, who do have God’s law, will be judged by that law when they fail to obey it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For merely listening to the law doesn’t make us right with God. It is obeying the law that makes us right in his sight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even Gentiles, who do not have God’s written law, show that they know his law when they instinctively obey it, even without having heard it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They demonstrate that God’s law is written in their hearts, for their own conscience and thoughts either accuse them or tell them they are doing right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And this is the message I proclaim—that the day is coming when God, through Christ Jesus, will judge everyone’s secret life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You who call yourselves Jews are relying on God’s law, and you boast about your special relationship with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You know what he wants; you know what is right because you have been taught his law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are convinced that you are a guide for the blind and a light for people who are lost in darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You think you can instruct the ignorant and teach children the ways of God. For you are certain that God’s law gives you complete knowledge and truth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Well then, if you teach others, why don’t you teach yourself? You tell others not to steal, but do you steal?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You say it is wrong to commit adultery, but do you commit adultery? You condemn idolatry, but do you use items stolen from pagan temples?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are so proud of knowing the law, but you dishonor God by breaking it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No wonder the Scriptures say, “The Gentiles blaspheme the name of God because of you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Jewish ceremony of circumcision has value only if you obey God’s law. But if you don’t obey God’s law, you are no better off than an uncircumcised Gentile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if the Gentiles obey God’s law, won’t God declare them to be his own people?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In fact, uncircumcised Gentiles who keep God’s law will condemn you Jews who are circumcised and possess God’s law but don’t obey it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For you are not a true Jew just because you were born of Jewish parents or because you have gone through the ceremony of circumcision.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No, a true Jew is one whose heart is right with God. And true circumcision is not merely obeying the letter of the law; rather, it is a change of heart produced by the Spirit. And a person with a changed heart seeks praise from God, not from people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then what’s the advantage of being a Jew? Is there any value in the ceremony of circumcision?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, there are great benefits! First of all, the Jews were entrusted with the whole revelation of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: True, some of them were unfaithful; but just because they were unfaithful, does that mean God will be unfaithful?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Of course not! Even if everyone else is a liar, God is true. As the Scriptures say about him, 
“You will be proved right in what you say,
    and you will win your case in court.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But,” some might say, “our sinfulness serves a good purpose, for it helps people see how righteous God is. Isn’t it unfair, then, for him to punish us?” (This is merely a human point of view.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Of course not! If God were not entirely fair, how would he be qualified to judge the world?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But,” someone might still argue, “how can God condemn me as a sinner if my dishonesty highlights his truthfulness and brings him more glory?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And some people even slander us by claiming that we say, “The more we sin, the better it is!” Those who say such things deserve to be condemned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Well then, should we conclude that we Jews are better than others? No, not at all, for we have already shown that all people, whether Jews or Gentiles, are under the power of sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As the Scriptures say,
“No one is righteous—
    not even one.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No one is truly wise;
    no one is seeking God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All have turned away;
    all have become useless.
No one does good,
    not a single one.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Their talk is foul, like the stench from an open grave.
    Their tongues are filled with lies.”
“Snake venom drips from their lips.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Their mouths are full of cursing and bitterness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “They rush to commit murder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Destruction and misery always follow them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They don’t know where to find peace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “They have no fear of God at all.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Obviously, the law applies to those to whom it was given, for its purpose is to keep people from having excuses, and to show that the entire world is guilty before God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For no one can ever be made right with God by doing what the law commands. The law simply shows us how sinful we are.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now God has shown us a way to be made right with him without keeping the requirements of the law, as was promised in the writings of Moses and the prophets long ago.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We are made right with God by placing our faith in Jesus Christ. And this is true for everyone who believes, no matter who we are.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For everyone has sinned; we all fall short of God’s glorious standard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet God, in his grace, freely makes us right in his sight. He did this through Christ Jesus when he freed us from the penalty for our sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For God presented Jesus as the sacrifice for sin. People are made right with God when they believe that Jesus sacrificed his life, shedding his blood. This sacrifice shows that God was being fair when he held back and did not punish those who sinned in times past,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for he was looking ahead and including them in what he would do in this present time. God did this to demonstrate his righteousness, for he himself is fair and just, and he makes sinners right in his sight when they believe in Jesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Can we boast, then, that we have done anything to be accepted by God? No, because our acquittal is not based on obeying the law. It is based on faith.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So we are made right with God through faith and not by obeying the law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all, is God the God of the Jews only? Isn’t he also the God of the Gentiles? Of course he is.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is only one God, and he makes people right with himself only by faith, whether they are Jews or Gentiles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Well then, if we emphasize faith, does this mean that we can forget about the law? Of course not! In fact, only when we have faith do we truly fulfill the law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham was, humanly speaking, the founder of our Jewish nation. What did he discover about being made right with God?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If his good deeds had made him acceptable to God, he would have had something to boast about. But that was not God’s way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the Scriptures tell us, “Abraham believed God, and God counted him as righteous because of his faith.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When people work, their wages are not a gift, but something they have earned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But people are counted as righteous, not because of their work, but because of their faith in God who forgives sinners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David also spoke of this when he described the happiness of those who are declared righteous without working for it:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Oh, what joy for those
    whose disobedience is forgiven,
    whose sins are put out of sight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, what joy for those
    whose record the Lord has cleared of sin.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, is this blessing only for the Jews, or is it also for uncircumcised Gentiles? Well, we have been saying that Abraham was counted as righteous by God because of his faith.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But how did this happen? Was he counted as righteous only after he was circumcised, or was it before he was circumcised? Clearly, God accepted Abraham before he was circumcised!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Circumcision was a sign that Abraham already had faith and that God had already accepted him and declared him to be righteous—even before he was circumcised. So Abraham is the spiritual father of those who have faith but have not been circumcised. They are counted as righteous because of their faith.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Abraham is also the spiritual father of those who have been circumcised, but only if they have the same kind of faith Abraham had before he was circumcised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Clearly, God’s promise to give the whole earth to Abraham and his descendants was based not on his obedience to God’s law, but on a right relationship with God that comes by faith.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If God’s promise is only for those who obey the law, then faith is not necessary and the promise is pointless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the law always brings punishment on those who try to obey it. (The only way to avoid breaking the law is to have no law to break!)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the promise is received by faith. It is given as a free gift. And we are all certain to receive it, whether or not we live according to the law of Moses, if we have faith like Abraham’s. For Abraham is the father of all who believe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is what the Scriptures mean when God told him, “I have made you the father of many nations.” This happened because Abraham believed in the God who brings the dead back to life and who creates new things out of nothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even when there was no reason for hope, Abraham kept hoping—believing that he would become the father of many nations. For God had said to him, “That’s how many descendants you will have!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Abraham’s faith did not weaken, even though, at about 100 years of age, he figured his body was as good as dead—and so was Sarah’s womb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham never wavered in believing God’s promise. In fact, his faith grew stronger, and in this he brought glory to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was fully convinced that God is able to do whatever he promises.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And because of Abraham’s faith, God counted him as righteous.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when God counted him as righteous, it wasn’t just for Abraham’s benefit. It was recorded
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for our benefit, too, assuring us that God will also count us as righteous if we believe in him, the one who raised Jesus our Lord from the dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was handed over to die because of our sins, and he was raised to life to make us right with God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, since we have been made right in God’s sight by faith, we have peace with God because of what Jesus Christ our Lord has done for us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because of our faith, Christ has brought us into this place of undeserved privilege where we now stand, and we confidently and joyfully look forward to sharing God’s glory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We can rejoice, too, when we run into problems and trials, for we know that they help us develop endurance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And endurance develops strength of character, and character strengthens our confident hope of salvation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And this hope will not lead to disappointment. For we know how dearly God loves us, because he has given us the Holy Spirit to fill our hearts with his love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we were utterly helpless, Christ came at just the right time and died for us sinners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, most people would not be willing to die for an upright person, though someone might perhaps be willing to die for a person who is especially good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God showed his great love for us by sending Christ to die for us while we were still sinners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And since we have been made right in God’s sight by the blood of Christ, he will certainly save us from God’s condemnation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For since our friendship with God was restored by the death of his Son while we were still his enemies, we will certainly be saved through the life of his Son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now we can rejoice in our wonderful new relationship with God because our Lord Jesus Christ has made us friends of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Adam sinned, sin entered the world. Adam’s sin brought death, so death spread to everyone, for everyone sinned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, people sinned even before the law was given. But it was not counted as sin because there was not yet any law to break.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Still, everyone died—from the time of Adam to the time of Moses—even those who did not disobey an explicit commandment of God, as Adam did. Now Adam is a symbol, a representation of Christ, who was yet to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But there is a great difference between Adam’s sin and God’s gracious gift. For the sin of this one man, Adam, brought death to many. But even greater is God’s wonderful grace and his gift of forgiveness to many through this other man, Jesus Christ.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the result of God’s gracious gift is very different from the result of that one man’s sin. For Adam’s sin led to condemnation, but God’s free gift leads to our being made right with God, even though we are guilty of many sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the sin of this one man, Adam, caused death to rule over many. But even greater is God’s wonderful grace and his gift of righteousness, for all who receive it will live in triumph over sin and death through this one man, Jesus Christ.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, Adam’s one sin brings condemnation for everyone, but Christ’s one act of righteousness brings a right relationship with God and new life for everyone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because one person disobeyed God, many became sinners. But because one other person obeyed God, many will be made righteous.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God’s law was given so that all people could see how sinful they were. But as people sinned more and more, God’s wonderful grace became more abundant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So just as sin ruled over all people and brought them to death, now God’s wonderful grace rules instead, giving us right standing with God and resulting in eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Well then, should we keep on sinning so that God can show us more and more of his wonderful grace?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Of course not! Since we have died to sin, how can we continue to live in it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Or have you forgotten that when we were joined with Christ Jesus in baptism, we joined him in his death?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For we died and were buried with Christ by baptism. And just as Christ was raised from the dead by the glorious power of the Father, now we also may live new lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since we have been united with him in his death, we will also be raised to life as he was.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We know that our old sinful selves were crucified with Christ so that sin might lose its power in our lives. We are no longer slaves to sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For when we died with Christ we were set free from the power of sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And since we died with Christ, we know we will also live with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We are sure of this because Christ was raised from the dead, and he will never die again. Death no longer has any power over him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he died, he died once to break the power of sin. But now that he lives, he lives for the glory of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So you also should consider yourselves to be dead to the power of sin and alive to God through Christ Jesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not let sin control the way you live; do not give in to sinful desires.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not let any part of your body become an instrument of evil to serve sin. Instead, give yourselves completely to God, for you were dead, but now you have new life. So use your whole body as an instrument to do what is right for the glory of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sin is no longer your master, for you no longer live under the requirements of the law. Instead, you live under the freedom of God’s grace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Well then, since God’s grace has set us free from the law, does that mean we can go on sinning? Of course not!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t you realize that you become the slave of whatever you choose to obey? You can be a slave to sin, which leads to death, or you can choose to obey God, which leads to righteous living.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thank God! Once you were slaves of sin, but now you wholeheartedly obey this teaching we have given you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now you are free from your slavery to sin, and you have become slaves to righteous living.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because of the weakness of your human nature, I am using the illustration of slavery to help you understand all this. Previously, you let yourselves be slaves to impurity and lawlessness, which led ever deeper into sin. Now you must give yourselves to be slaves to righteous living so that you will become holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you were slaves to sin, you were free from the obligation to do right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And what was the result? You are now ashamed of the things you used to do, things that end in eternal doom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now you are free from the power of sin and have become slaves of God. Now you do those things that lead to holiness and result in eternal life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the wages of sin is death, but the free gift of God is eternal life through Christ Jesus our Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, dear brothers and sisters—you who are familiar with the law—don’t you know that the law applies only while a person is living?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For example, when a woman marries, the law binds her to her husband as long as he is alive. But if he dies, the laws of marriage no longer apply to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So while her husband is alive, she would be committing adultery if she married another man. But if her husband dies, she is free from that law and does not commit adultery when she remarries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So, my dear brothers and sisters, this is the point: You died to the power of the law when you died with Christ. And now you are united with the one who was raised from the dead. As a result, we can produce a harvest of good deeds for God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we were controlled by our old nature, sinful desires were at work within us, and the law aroused these evil desires that produced a harvest of sinful deeds, resulting in death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now we have been released from the law, for we died to it and are no longer captive to its power. Now we can serve God, not in the old way of obeying the letter of the law, but in the new way of living in the Spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Well then, am I suggesting that the law of God is sinful? Of course not! In fact, it was the law that showed me my sin. I would never have known that coveting is wrong if the law had not said, “You must not covet.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But sin used this command to arouse all kinds of covetous desires within me! If there were no law, sin would not have that power.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At one time I lived without understanding the law. But when I learned the command not to covet, for instance, the power of sin came to life,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I died. So I discovered that the law’s commands, which were supposed to bring life, brought spiritual death instead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sin took advantage of those commands and deceived me; it used the commands to kill me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But still, the law itself is holy, and its commands are holy and right and good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But how can that be? Did the law, which is good, cause my death? Of course not! Sin used what was good to bring about my condemnation to death. So we can see how terrible sin really is. It uses God’s good commands for its own evil purposes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the trouble is not with the law, for it is spiritual and good. The trouble is with me, for I am all too human, a slave to sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I don’t really understand myself, for I want to do what is right, but I don’t do it. Instead, I do what I hate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if I know that what I am doing is wrong, this shows that I agree that the law is good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I am not the one doing wrong; it is sin living in me that does it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I know that nothing good lives in me, that is, in my sinful nature. I want to do what is right, but I can’t.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I want to do what is good, but I don’t. I don’t want to do what is wrong, but I do it anyway.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if I do what I don’t want to do, I am not really the one doing wrong; it is sin living in me that does it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have discovered this principle of life—that when I want to do what is right, I inevitably do what is wrong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I love God’s law with all my heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But there is another power within me that is at war with my mind. This power makes me a slave to the sin that is still within me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Oh, what a miserable person I am! Who will free me from this life that is dominated by sin and death?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thank God! The answer is in Jesus Christ our Lord. So you see how it is: In my mind I really want to obey God’s law, but because of my sinful nature I am a slave to sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now there is no condemnation for those who belong to Christ Jesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And because you belong to him, the power of the life-giving Spirit has freed you from the power of sin that leads to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The law of Moses was unable to save us because of the weakness of our sinful nature. So God did what the law could not do. He sent his own Son in a body like the bodies we sinners have. And in that body God declared an end to sin’s control over us by giving his Son as a sacrifice for our sins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did this so that the just requirement of the law would be fully satisfied for us, who no longer follow our sinful nature but instead follow the Spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who are dominated by the sinful nature think about sinful things, but those who are controlled by the Holy Spirit think about things that please the Spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So letting your sinful nature control your mind leads to death. But letting the Spirit control your mind leads to life and peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the sinful nature is always hostile to God. It never did obey God’s laws, and it never will.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That’s why those who are still under the control of their sinful nature can never please God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you are not controlled by your sinful nature. You are controlled by the Spirit if you have the Spirit of God living in you. (And remember that those who do not have the Spirit of Christ living in them do not belong to him at all.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Christ lives within you, so even though your body will die because of sin, the Spirit gives you life because you have been made right with God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Spirit of God, who raised Jesus from the dead, lives in you. And just as God raised Christ Jesus from the dead, he will give life to your mortal bodies by this same Spirit living within you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, dear brothers and sisters, you have no obligation to do what your sinful nature urges you to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For if you live by its dictates, you will die. But if through the power of the Spirit you put to death the deeds of your sinful nature, you will live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For all who are led by the Spirit of God are children of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So you have not received a spirit that makes you fearful slaves. Instead, you received God’s Spirit when he adopted you as his own children. Now we call him, “Abba, Father.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For his Spirit joins with our spirit to affirm that we are God’s children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And since we are his children, we are his heirs. In fact, together with Christ we are heirs of God’s glory. But if we are to share his glory, we must also share his suffering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet what we suffer now is nothing compared to the glory he will reveal to us later.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For all creation is waiting eagerly for that future day when God will reveal who his children really are.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Against its will, all creation was subjected to God’s curse. But with eager hope,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the creation looks forward to the day when it will join God’s children in glorious freedom from death and decay.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For we know that all creation has been groaning as in the pains of childbirth right up to the present time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And we believers also groan, even though we have the Holy Spirit within us as a foretaste of future glory, for we long for our bodies to be released from sin and suffering. We, too, wait with eager hope for the day when God will give us our full rights as his adopted children, including the new bodies he has promised us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We were given this hope when we were saved. (If we already have something, we don’t need to hope for it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if we look forward to something we don’t yet have, we must wait patiently and confidently.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Holy Spirit helps us in our weakness. For example, we don’t know what God wants us to pray for. But the Holy Spirit prays for us with groanings that cannot be expressed in words.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Father who knows all hearts knows what the Spirit is saying, for the Spirit pleads for us believers in harmony with God’s own will.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And we know that God causes everything to work together for the good of those who love God and are called according to his purpose for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For God knew his people in advance, and he chose them to become like his Son, so that his Son would be the firstborn among many brothers and sisters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And having chosen them, he called them to come to him. And having called them, he gave them right standing with himself. And having given them right standing, he gave them his glory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What shall we say about such wonderful things as these? If God is for us, who can ever be against us?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since he did not spare even his own Son but gave him up for us all, won’t he also give us everything else?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who dares accuse us whom God has chosen for his own? No one—for God himself has given us right standing with himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who then will condemn us? No one—for Christ Jesus died for us and was raised to life for us, and he is sitting in the place of honor at God’s right hand, pleading for us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Can anything ever separate us from Christ’s love? Does it mean he no longer loves us if we have trouble or calamity, or are persecuted, or hungry, or destitute, or in danger, or threatened with death?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (As the Scriptures say, “For your sake we are killed every day; we are being slaughtered like sheep.”)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No, despite all these things, overwhelming victory is ours through Christ, who loved us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I am convinced that nothing can ever separate us from God’s love. Neither death nor life, neither angels nor demons, neither our fears for today nor our worries about tomorrow—not even the powers of hell can separate us from God’s love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No power in the sky above or in the earth below—indeed, nothing in all creation will ever be able to separate us from the love of God that is revealed in Christ Jesus our Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With Christ as my witness, I speak with utter truthfulness. My conscience and the Holy Spirit confirm it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My heart is filled with bitter sorrow and unending grief
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for my people, my Jewish brothers and sisters. I would be willing to be forever cursed—cut off from Christ!—if that would save them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They are the people of Israel, chosen to be God’s adopted children. God revealed his glory to them. He made covenants with them and gave them his law. He gave them the privilege of worshiping him and receiving his wonderful promises.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob are their ancestors, and Christ himself was an Israelite as far as his human nature is concerned. And he is God, the one who rules over everything and is worthy of eternal praise! Amen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Well then, has God failed to fulfill his promise to Israel? No, for not all who are born into the nation of Israel are truly members of God’s people!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Being descendants of Abraham doesn’t make them truly Abraham’s children. For the Scriptures say, “Isaac is the son through whom your descendants will be counted,” though Abraham had other children, too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This means that Abraham’s physical descendants are not necessarily children of God. Only the children of the promise are considered to be Abraham’s children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For God had promised, “I will return about this time next year, and Sarah will have a son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This son was our ancestor Isaac. When he married Rebekah, she gave birth to twins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But before they were born, before they had done anything good or bad, she received a message from God. (This message shows that God chooses people according to his own purposes;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he calls people, but not according to their good or bad works.) She was told, “Your older son will serve your younger son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the words of the Scriptures, “I loved Jacob, but I rejected Esau.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Are we saying, then, that God was unfair? Of course not!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For God said to Moses,
“I will show mercy to anyone I choose,
    and I will show compassion to anyone I choose.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So it is God who decides to show mercy. We can neither choose it nor work for it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the Scriptures say that God told Pharaoh, “I have appointed you for the very purpose of displaying my power in you and to spread my fame throughout the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So you see, God chooses to show mercy to some, and he chooses to harden the hearts of others so they refuse to listen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Well then, you might say, “Why does God blame people for not responding? Haven’t they simply done what he makes them do?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No, don’t say that. Who are you, a mere human being, to argue with God? Should the thing that was created say to the one who created it, “Why have you made me like this?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When a potter makes jars out of clay, doesn’t he have a right to use the same lump of clay to make one jar for decoration and another to throw garbage into?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the same way, even though God has the right to show his anger and his power, he is very patient with those on whom his anger falls, who are destined for destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He does this to make the riches of his glory shine even brighter on those to whom he shows mercy, who were prepared in advance for glory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And we are among those whom he selected, both from the Jews and from the Gentiles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Concerning the Gentiles, God says in the prophecy of Hosea,
“Those who were not my people,
    I will now call my people.
And I will love those
    whom I did not love before.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And,
“Then, at the place where they were told,
    ‘You are not my people,’
there they will be called
    ‘children of the living God.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And concerning Israel, Isaiah the prophet cried out,
“Though the people of Israel are as numerous as the sand of the seashore,
    only a remnant will be saved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For the Lord will carry out his sentence upon the earth
    quickly and with finality.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And Isaiah said the same thing in another place:
“If the Lord of Heaven’s Armies
    had not spared a few of our children,
we would have been wiped out like Sodom,
    destroyed like Gomorrah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What does all this mean? Even though the Gentiles were not trying to follow God’s standards, they were made right with God. And it was by faith that this took place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people of Israel, who tried so hard to get right with God by keeping the law, never succeeded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why not? Because they were trying to get right with God by keeping the law instead of by trusting in him. They stumbled over the great rock in their path.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God warned them of this in the Scriptures when he said, 
“I am placing a stone in Jerusalem that makes people stumble,
    a rock that makes them fall.
But anyone who trusts in him
    will never be disgraced.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dear brothers and sisters, the longing of my heart and my prayer to God is for the people of Israel to be saved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I know what enthusiasm they have for God, but it is misdirected zeal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For they don’t understand God’s way of making people right with himself. Refusing to accept God’s way, they cling to their own way of getting right with God by trying to keep the law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For Christ has already accomplished the purpose for which the law was given. As a result, all who believe in him are made right with God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For Moses writes that the law’s way of making a person right with God requires obedience to all of its commands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But faith’s way of getting right with God says, “Don’t say in your heart, ‘Who will go up to heaven?’ (to bring Christ down to earth).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And don’t say, ‘Who will go down to the place of the dead?’ (to bring Christ back to life again).”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In fact, it says,
“The message is very close at hand;
    it is on your lips and in your heart.”
And that message is the very message about faith that we preach:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you openly declare that Jesus is Lord and believe in your heart that God raised him from the dead, you will be saved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For it is by believing in your heart that you are made right with God, and it is by openly declaring your faith that you are saved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the Scriptures tell us, “Anyone who trusts in him will never be disgraced.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jew and Gentile are the same in this respect. They have the same Lord, who gives generously to all who call on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For “Everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But how can they call on him to save them unless they believe in him? And how can they believe in him if they have never heard about him? And how can they hear about him unless someone tells them?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And how will anyone go and tell them without being sent? That is why the Scriptures say, “How beautiful are the feet of messengers who bring good news!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But not everyone welcomes the Good News, for Isaiah the prophet said, “Lord, who has believed our message?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So faith comes from hearing, that is, hearing the Good News about Christ.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I ask, have the people of Israel actually heard the message? Yes, they have:
“The message has gone throughout the earth,
    and the words to all the world.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I ask, did the people of Israel really understand? Yes, they did, for even in the time of Moses, God said, 
“I will rouse your jealousy through people who are not even a nation.
    I will provoke your anger through the foolish Gentiles.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And later Isaiah spoke boldly for God, saying,
“I was found by people who were not looking for me.
    I showed myself to those who were not asking for me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But regarding Israel, God said,
“All day long I opened my arms to them,
    but they were disobedient and rebellious.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I ask, then, has God rejected his own people, the nation of Israel? Of course not! I myself am an Israelite, a descendant of Abraham and a member of the tribe of Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No, God has not rejected his own people, whom he chose from the very beginning. Do you realize what the Scriptures say about this? Elijah the prophet complained to God about the people of Israel and said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Lord, they have killed your prophets and torn down your altars. I am the only one left, and now they are trying to kill me, too.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And do you remember God’s reply? He said, “No, I have 7,000 others who have never bowed down to Baal!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is the same today, for a few of the people of Israel have remained faithful because of God’s grace—his undeserved kindness in choosing them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And since it is through God’s kindness, then it is not by their good works. For in that case, God’s grace would not be what it really is—free and undeserved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So this is the situation: Most of the people of Israel have not found the favor of God they are looking for so earnestly. A few have—the ones God has chosen—but the hearts of the rest were hardened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As the Scriptures say,
“God has put them into a deep sleep.
To this day he has shut their eyes so they do not see,
    and closed their ears so they do not hear.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Likewise, David said,
“Let their bountiful table become a snare,
    a trap that makes them think all is well.
Let their blessings cause them to stumble,
    and let them get what they deserve.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let their eyes go blind so they cannot see,
    and let their backs be bent forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Did God’s people stumble and fall beyond recovery? Of course not! They were disobedient, so God made salvation available to the Gentiles. But he wanted his own people to become jealous and claim it for themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now if the Gentiles were enriched because the people of Israel turned down God’s offer of salvation, think how much greater a blessing the world will share when they finally accept it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am saying all this especially for you Gentiles. God has appointed me as the apostle to the Gentiles. I stress this,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for I want somehow to make the people of Israel jealous of what you Gentiles have, so I might save some of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For since their rejection meant that God offered salvation to the rest of the world, their acceptance will be even more wonderful. It will be life for those who were dead!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And since Abraham and the other patriarchs were holy, their descendants will also be holy—just as the entire batch of dough is holy because the portion given as an offering is holy. For if the roots of the tree are holy, the branches will be, too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But some of these branches from Abraham’s tree—some of the people of Israel—have been broken off. And you Gentiles, who were branches from a wild olive tree, have been grafted in. So now you also receive the blessing God has promised Abraham and his children, sharing in the rich nourishment from the root of God’s special olive tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you must not brag about being grafted in to replace the branches that were broken off. You are just a branch, not the root.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Well,” you may say, “those branches were broken off to make room for me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, but remember—those branches were broken off because they didn’t believe in Christ, and you are there because you do believe. So don’t think highly of yourself, but fear what could happen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For if God did not spare the original branches, he won’t spare you either.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Notice how God is both kind and severe. He is severe toward those who disobeyed, but kind to you if you continue to trust in his kindness. But if you stop trusting, you also will be cut off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if the people of Israel turn from their unbelief, they will be grafted in again, for God has the power to graft them back into the tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You, by nature, were a branch cut from a wild olive tree. So if God was willing to do something contrary to nature by grafting you into his cultivated tree, he will be far more eager to graft the original branches back into the tree where they belong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I want you to understand this mystery, dear brothers and sisters, so that you will not feel proud about yourselves. Some of the people of Israel have hard hearts, but this will last only until the full number of Gentiles comes to Christ.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And so all Israel will be saved. As the Scriptures say,
“The one who rescues will come from Jerusalem,
    and he will turn Israel away from ungodliness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And this is my covenant with them,
    that I will take away their sins.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many of the people of Israel are now enemies of the Good News, and this benefits you Gentiles. Yet they are still the people he loves because he chose their ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For God’s gifts and his call can never be withdrawn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once, you Gentiles were rebels against God, but when the people of Israel rebelled against him, God was merciful to you instead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now they are the rebels, and God’s mercy has come to you so that they, too, will share in God’s mercy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For God has imprisoned everyone in disobedience so he could have mercy on everyone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Oh, how great are God’s riches and wisdom and knowledge! How impossible it is for us to understand his decisions and his ways!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For who can know the Lord’s thoughts?
    Who knows enough to give him advice?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And who has given him so much
    that he needs to pay it back?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For everything comes from him and exists by his power and is intended for his glory. All glory to him forever! Amen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so, dear brothers and sisters, I plead with you to give your bodies to God because of all he has done for you. Let them be a living and holy sacrifice—the kind he will find acceptable. This is truly the way to worship him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t copy the behavior and customs of this world, but let God transform you into a new person by changing the way you think. Then you will learn to know God’s will for you, which is good and pleasing and perfect.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because of the privilege and authority God has given me, I give each of you this warning: Don’t think you are better than you really are. Be honest in your evaluation of yourselves, measuring yourselves by the faith God has given us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just as our bodies have many parts and each part has a special function,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so it is with Christ’s body. We are many parts of one body, and we all belong to each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In his grace, God has given us different gifts for doing certain things well. So if God has given you the ability to prophesy, speak out with as much faith as God has given you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If your gift is serving others, serve them well. If you are a teacher, teach well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If your gift is to encourage others, be encouraging. If it is giving, give generously. If God has given you leadership ability, take the responsibility seriously. And if you have a gift for showing kindness to others, do it gladly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t just pretend to love others. Really love them. Hate what is wrong. Hold tightly to what is good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Love each other with genuine affection, and take delight in honoring each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Never be lazy, but work hard and serve the Lord enthusiastically.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rejoice in our confident hope. Be patient in trouble, and keep on praying.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When God’s people are in need, be ready to help them. Always be eager to practice hospitality.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bless those who persecute you. Don’t curse them; pray that God will bless them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be happy with those who are happy, and weep with those who weep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Live in harmony with each other. Don’t be too proud to enjoy the company of ordinary people. And don’t think you know it all!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Never pay back evil with more evil. Do things in such a way that everyone can see you are honorable.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do all that you can to live in peace with everyone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Dear friends, never take revenge. Leave that to the righteous anger of God. For the Scriptures say,
“I will take revenge;
    I will pay them back,”
    says the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Instead, 
“If your enemies are hungry, feed them.
    If they are thirsty, give them something to drink.
In doing this, you will heap
    burning coals of shame on their heads.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t let evil conquer you, but conquer evil by doing good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone must submit to governing authorities. For all authority comes from God, and those in positions of authority have been placed there by God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So anyone who rebels against authority is rebelling against what God has instituted, and they will be punished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the authorities do not strike fear in people who are doing right, but in those who are doing wrong. Would you like to live without fear of the authorities? Do what is right, and they will honor you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The authorities are God’s servants, sent for your good. But if you are doing wrong, of course you should be afraid, for they have the power to punish you. They are God’s servants, sent for the very purpose of punishing those who do what is wrong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So you must submit to them, not only to avoid punishment, but also to keep a clear conscience.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pay your taxes, too, for these same reasons. For government workers need to be paid. They are serving God in what they do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give to everyone what you owe them: Pay your taxes and government fees to those who collect them, and give respect and honor to those who are in authority.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Owe nothing to anyone—except for your obligation to love one another. If you love your neighbor, you will fulfill the requirements of God’s law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the commandments say, “You must not commit adultery. You must not murder. You must not steal. You must not covet.” These—and other such commandments—are summed up in this one commandment: “Love your neighbor as yourself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Love does no wrong to others, so love fulfills the requirements of God’s law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is all the more urgent, for you know how late it is; time is running out. Wake up, for our salvation is nearer now than when we first believed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The night is almost gone; the day of salvation will soon be here. So remove your dark deeds like dirty clothes, and put on the shining armor of right living.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because we belong to the day, we must live decent lives for all to see. Don’t participate in the darkness of wild parties and drunkenness, or in sexual promiscuity and immoral living, or in quarreling and jealousy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, clothe yourself with the presence of the Lord Jesus Christ. And don’t let yourself think about ways to indulge your evil desires.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Accept other believers who are weak in faith, and don’t argue with them about what they think is right or wrong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For instance, one person believes it’s all right to eat anything. But another believer with a sensitive conscience will eat only vegetables.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who feel free to eat anything must not look down on those who don’t. And those who don’t eat certain foods must not condemn those who do, for God has accepted them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who are you to condemn someone else’s servants? Their own master will judge whether they stand or fall. And with the Lord’s help, they will stand and receive his approval.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the same way, some think one day is more holy than another day, while others think every day is alike. You should each be fully convinced that whichever day you choose is acceptable.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who worship the Lord on a special day do it to honor him. Those who eat any kind of food do so to honor the Lord, since they give thanks to God before eating. And those who refuse to eat certain foods also want to please the Lord and give thanks to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For we don’t live for ourselves or die for ourselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If we live, it’s to honor the Lord. And if we die, it’s to honor the Lord. So whether we live or die, we belong to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Christ died and rose again for this very purpose—to be Lord both of the living and of the dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So why do you condemn another believer? Why do you look down on another believer? Remember, we will all stand before the judgment seat of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For the Scriptures say, 
“‘As surely as I live,’ says the Lord,
‘every knee will bend to me,
    and every tongue will declare allegiance to God.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, each of us will give a personal account to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So let’s stop condemning each other. Decide instead to live in such a way that you will not cause another believer to stumble and fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I know and am convinced on the authority of the Lord Jesus that no food, in and of itself, is wrong to eat. But if someone believes it is wrong, then for that person it is wrong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if another believer is distressed by what you eat, you are not acting in love if you eat it. Don’t let your eating ruin someone for whom Christ died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then you will not be criticized for doing something you believe is good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the Kingdom of God is not a matter of what we eat or drink, but of living a life of goodness and peace and joy in the Holy Spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you serve Christ with this attitude, you will please God, and others will approve of you, too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So then, let us aim for harmony in the church and try to build each other up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t tear apart the work of God over what you eat. Remember, all foods are acceptable, but it is wrong to eat something if it makes another person stumble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is better not to eat meat or drink wine or do anything else if it might cause another believer to stumble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You may believe there’s nothing wrong with what you are doing, but keep it between yourself and God. Blessed are those who don’t feel guilty for doing something they have decided is right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you have doubts about whether or not you should eat something, you are sinning if you go ahead and do it. For you are not following your convictions. If you do anything you believe is not right, you are sinning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We who are strong must be considerate of those who are sensitive about things like this. We must not just please ourselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We should help others do what is right and build them up in the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For even Christ didn’t live to please himself. As the Scriptures say, “The insults of those who insult you, O God, have fallen on me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Such things were written in the Scriptures long ago to teach us. And the Scriptures give us hope and encouragement as we wait patiently for God’s promises to be fulfilled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May God, who gives this patience and encouragement, help you live in complete harmony with each other, as is fitting for followers of Christ Jesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all of you can join together with one voice, giving praise and glory to God, the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, accept each other just as Christ has accepted you so that God will be given glory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Remember that Christ came as a servant to the Jews to show that God is true to the promises he made to their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
And in another place it is written,
“Rejoice with his people,
    you Gentiles.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And yet again,
“Praise the Lord, all you Gentiles.
    Praise him, all you people of the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And in another place Isaiah said, 
“The heir to David’s throne will come,
    and he will rule over the Gentiles.
They will place their hope on him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I pray that God, the source of hope, will fill you completely with joy and peace because you trust in him. Then you will overflow with confident hope through the power of the Holy Spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am fully convinced, my dear brothers and sisters, that you are full of goodness. You know these things so well you can teach each other all about them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even so, I have been bold enough to write about some of these points, knowing that all you need is this reminder. For by God’s grace,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am a special messenger from Christ Jesus to you Gentiles. I bring you the Good News so that I might present you as an acceptable offering to God, made holy by the Holy Spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I have reason to be enthusiastic about all Christ Jesus has done through me in my service to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet I dare not boast about anything except what Christ has done through me, bringing the Gentiles to God by my message and by the way I worked among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were convinced by the power of miraculous signs and wonders and by the power of God’s Spirit. In this way, I have fully presented the Good News of Christ from Jerusalem all the way to Illyricum.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My ambition has always been to preach the Good News where the name of Christ has never been heard, rather than where a church has already been started by someone else.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have been following the plan spoken of in the Scriptures, where it says, 
“Those who have never been told about him will see,
    and those who have never heard of him will understand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In fact, my visit to you has been delayed so long because I have been preaching in these places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now I have finished my work in these regions, and after all these long years of waiting, I am eager to visit you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am planning to go to Spain, and when I do, I will stop off in Rome. And after I have enjoyed your fellowship for a little while, you can provide for my journey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But before I come, I must go to Jerusalem to take a gift to the believers there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For you see, the believers in Macedonia and Achaia have eagerly taken up an offering for the poor among the believers in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were glad to do this because they feel they owe a real debt to them. Since the Gentiles received the spiritual blessings of the Good News from the believers in Jerusalem, they feel the least they can do in return is to help them financially.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as I have delivered this money and completed this good deed of theirs, I will come to see you on my way to Spain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I am sure that when I come, Christ will richly bless our time together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dear brothers and sisters, I urge you in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ to join in my struggle by praying to God for me. Do this because of your love for me, given to you by the Holy Spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pray that I will be rescued from those in Judea who refuse to obey God. Pray also that the believers there will be willing to accept the donation I am taking to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then, by the will of God, I will be able to come to you with a joyful heart, and we will be an encouragement to each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now may God, who gives us his peace, be with you all. Amen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I commend to you our sister Phoebe, who is a deacon in the church in Cenchrea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Welcome her in the Lord as one who is worthy of honor among God’s people. Help her in whatever she needs, for she has been helpful to many, and especially to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give my greetings to Priscilla and Aquila, my co-workers in the ministry of Christ Jesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In fact, they once risked their lives for me. I am thankful to them, and so are all the Gentile churches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Also give my greetings to the church that meets in their home.
Greet my dear friend Epenetus. He was the first person from the province of Asia to become a follower of Christ.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give my greetings to Mary, who has worked so hard for your benefit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Greet Andronicus and Junia, my fellow Jews, who were in prison with me. They are highly respected among the apostles and became followers of Christ before I did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Greet Ampliatus, my dear friend in the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Greet Urbanus, our co-worker in Christ, and my dear friend Stachys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Greet Apelles, a good man whom Christ approves. And give my greetings to the believers from the household of Aristobulus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Greet Herodion, my fellow Jew. Greet the Lord’s people from the household of Narcissus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give my greetings to Tryphena and Tryphosa, the Lord’s workers, and to dear Persis, who has worked so hard for the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Greet Rufus, whom the Lord picked out to be his very own; and also his dear mother, who has been a mother to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give my greetings to Asyncritus, Phlegon, Hermes, Patrobas, Hermas, and the brothers and sisters who meet with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give my greetings to Philologus, Julia, Nereus and his sister, and to Olympas and all the believers who meet with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Greet each other with a sacred kiss. All the churches of Christ send you their greetings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now I make one more appeal, my dear brothers and sisters. Watch out for people who cause divisions and upset people’s faith by teaching things contrary to what you have been taught. Stay away from them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Such people are not serving Christ our Lord; they are serving their own personal interests. By smooth talk and glowing words they deceive innocent people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But everyone knows that you are obedient to the Lord. This makes me very happy. I want you to be wise in doing right and to stay innocent of any wrong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The God of peace will soon crush Satan under your feet. May the grace of our Lord Jesus be with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Timothy, my fellow worker, sends you his greetings, as do Lucius, Jason, and Sosipater, my fellow Jews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I, Tertius, the one writing this letter for Paul, send my greetings, too, as one of the Lord’s followers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gaius says hello to you. He is my host and also serves as host to the whole church. Erastus, the city treasurer, sends you his greetings, and so does our brother Quartus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now all glory to God, who is able to make you strong, just as my Good News says. This message about Jesus Christ has revealed his plan for you Gentiles, a plan kept secret from the beginning of time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now as the prophets foretold and as the eternal God has commanded, this message is made known to all Gentiles everywhere, so that they too might believe and obey him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All glory to the only wise God, through Jesus Christ, forever. Amen.
verses.speaker: Narrator
